evidence.text:
Person B: To cheer me up, Dad gave me Mum’s old jewellery box ... 
Person B: ... inside it had her snail collection and her ring ... She’d loved snails as well and had been a malacologist at the Melbourne Museum ...
Person B: ... I thought Gilbert should have it.

Person A: I’m gonna wear this till the day I die, Gracie ... 
Person B: Despite my woes, Sylvia ... I believed in glasses half full and silver linings. 
Person B: Our home was our sanctuary ... especially my bedroom.
Person B: Right angles brought me enormous comfort ... as did my snails. 
Person B: They were tangible memories of a mum I never met ... They were my friends ... 
Person B: ... so I made more of them ... I knew they’d never leave me ... hurt me ... or die. 
Person B: I didn’t like people dying ... Suddenly he shifts his weight. 
Person B: ... I wanted to save people ... save the homeless ... my favourite was James. 
Person B: One Christmas I covered him in decorations so he could feel some Christmas cheer. Grace looks happy and proud of herself. She takes some coins and teabags from her pocket and places them next to his drunken head. 
Person B: He loved tea.

Person A: We got little scars and when we put our arms together ....
Person A: ... they formed a face.
Person A: It felt great when we did this. Our feelings aligned ...
Person A: ... A lot of twins say this Sylvia, and it’s true. I felt his emotions ... his happiness ...

Person A: I’d rather eat glass ... Anyway, they can all get stuffed, coz as soon as I’m old enough and got money I’m comin to get you.
Person A: ... we’ll escape to Paris. I’ll become a fire-eater ...
Person A: ... and you’ll become an amazing animator.
Person A: ... it’ll be great!

Person B: Gilbert still smelt like burnt matches ... The setting sun tingled our skin ...
Person B: ... our two souls and single heart.
